Responder Chain Edit on GitHub

Components are subclasses of UIResponder, so they have a responder chain. Their responder chain is separate from UIView's responder chain, so you must manually bridge over to the component responder chain if desired.

TODO: pxcld

  1. The next responder of a component is its controller, if it has one.
  2. The next responder of a component's controller is its component's parent component.
  3. If a component doesn't have a controller, its next responder is its parent component.
  4. The next responder of the root component is the view that it is currently attached to via [CKComponentLifecycleManager -attachToView:].
  5. As normal, a view's next responder is its superview.
  6. Eventually, this will reach the same root view as the component hierarchy.
  7. It's up to you to manually bridge from the view responder chain into the component responder chain if desired by using CKComponentActionSend or one of the helpers described below.

Tap Handling

The easiest way to handle taps on UIControl views is to use CKComponentActionAttribute. It returns a component attribute that triggers a component action when any given UIControlEvent occurs. For example:

@implementation CKSomeComponent

+ (instancetype)new
{
  return [self newWithView:{
    [UIButton class],
    {CKComponentActionAttribute(@selector(didTapButton))}
  }];
}

- (void)didTapButton
{
  // Aha! The button has been tapped.
}

@end

Gestures

That works for UIControls, but what about other views? Fear not, you can use CKComponentTapGestureAttribute. This allows you to install a tap gesture recognizer on any UIView and be notified when the tap occurs.

@implementation CKSomeComponent

+ (instancetype)new
{
  return [self newWithView:{
    [UIView class],
    {CKComponentTapGestureAttribute(@selector(didTapView))}
  }];
}

- (void)didTapView
{
  // The view has been tapped.
}

@end

Advanced Gestures

What about advanced gestures like panning, pinching, swiping, and so on?

These are more complicated. The way the reactive-update model is implemented in Components is fairly limited, so we usually end up building an "escape hatch" from the reactive data flow for these at present. Come talk to us and we can help you out.
